text: hi everyone I'm Lindsay strand and today
on sweet talk I'm making Irish soda
bread drop scones this is our easy take
on the traditional st. Patrick's Day
treat starting with my dry ingredients
so I have 2 cups of all-purpose flour I
love these because these are just one
Bowl cup and then a quarter cup of
granulated sugar they're just a little
bit sweet but not too much a quarter
teaspoon of baking soda and then 2
teaspoons of baking powder this gives
these a nice rise this is very similar
to a biscuit dough and then a 1/2
teaspoon of kosher salt because as
always good to have salt in your sweets
so give the dry a quick whisk to combine
now that I have my dry I'm ready to add
butter this is one stick of cold
unsalted butter really important that
this is cold because this is going to
give you your flaky layers in your
scones so what I'm doing here is I'm
just pressing the butter with my fingers
to make little petals of cold butter
when the butter melts in your scones it
creates an air pocket which gives you
that lovely fluffy texture that you're
looking for
you can also use a pastry cutter but I
kind of like getting my hands in there
and getting a little bit dirty with this
one so you're just looking for pea-sized
clumps to be a really good activity for
the kids to help out with their little
hands are perfect for this when I was
thinking of a st. Patrick's Day treat I
immediately thought of my stepmom
because she comes from a big Irish
family they are the Duffy's and every
year her mom makes Irish soda bread and
they always cut off little slivers and
it seems like the loaf lasts for weeks I
mean it's delicious but if you've ever
had Irish soda bread it makes a lot of
soda bread so I was trying to think how
do I turn this into more of a
single-serving
fun thing you could bring to a brunch
you could bring it to your st. Patrick's
Day party and I came up with these drops
cones which are just so easy they bake
in a lot less
time to so this is looking good now I'm
adding my wet ingredients which is just
a cup of buttermilk
so moisten everything nicely and then
throwing in a half cup of currants this
is kind of traditional to Irish soda
bread and two teaspoons of caraway seeds
this is another really traditional
flavor mix these together if you really
like caraway you could always up this to
a tablespoon but I found that two
teaspoons was just the perfect amount
for me so you're looking to get these
just moistened you don't want to over
mix them otherwise they'll get tough
caraway seeds are really nice here
because they add a little bit of almost
a licorice II taste now I just have an
ice cream scoop you could always use two
spoons for this but this is really easy
to get same sized scoops and I'm just
going to drop them right on my baking
sheet hence the name drop scones and
this makes eight scones which i think is
a nice amount for a party or maybe
having enough for your family for a
couple of breakfasts
[Music]
it's a pretty sticky dough so if you are
using two spoons you might have to
maneuver it a little bit have to scrape
the bowl for that last one just like
that they are ready to go in the oven my
oven is preheated to 425 degrees and
they will bake for 15 to 20 minutes
until the bottoms are golden and the
tops are just set my scones are ready
I've let them cool completely which is
the hardest part because they smell so
good fresh out of the oven and you could
definitely eat them as is but I like to
add a little orange glaze so for that I
have a cup of confectioner's sugar two
tablespoons of whole milk just whisk
this to combine should be a nice drizzly
glaze
and then I'm adding a quarter teaspoon
of orange zest which adds such a nice
fragrance citrusy flavor plays really
nicely with the currants and caraway I
love the smell of orange zest that looks
about good just adds a really nice
pretty color get all the lumps out of
the glaze and now I'm just drizzling
this over my scones they have nice Craig
Lee tops to catch all of that delicious
glaze and I've put a piece of parchment
paper under my rack here just in case to
catch the drips just so that I don't
make a mess on my counter wow this looks
so good the orange smells amazing this
is a perfect treat to brighten up a
March day its citrus season so you love
having that little hint of citrus in
there who else needs a little more love
here I've got one last little bit
there you have it these are Irish soda
bread drop scones normally I would let
the glaze harden a little bit to set up
it takes about ten minutes but these
look so good I obviously have to eat one
right now
Wow look how fluffy and tender that
scone looks that is from all of that
cold butter
you have the currants caraway this looks
delicious
I hope you'll give these a try for your
st. Patrick's Day celebration enjoy I
really taste you if you're enjoying this
video be sure to like subscribe we have
so many great fun videos on the everyday
food Channel
you
